So here we are.

I’m taking my responsibility as a Representative very seriously to follow the law, to thoroughly understand constitutional issues and listen to the outrage of nearly 70 million Americans as we approach January 6th.

A number of these issues were forecasted in the bipartisan 2005 election commission led by Jimmy Carter & James Baker.

Numerous reforms were recommended then.

But Congress and states refused to make the reforms necessary to prevent our present situation.

Every American should want to see these issues fully addressed & resolved so we can move forward.

Not just for this election but for future elections.

Here’s what I can tell you — in 2020, several states faced significant constitutional issues regarding election officials or state courts overriding the laws enacted by their state legislatures.

Numerous irregularities have been cited under affidavit.

In 2017, 10 House Dems objected to the results of the 2016 election, citing voter suppression & foreign interference.

They failed to get a Senator's signature & the challenge died.
https://www.politico.com/story/2017/01/no-trump-electoral-college-challenge-233294

In 2005, House Dems challenged Ohio's 20 electoral votes due to claims of voting irregularities.

Dems claimed they were drawing attention to the need for aggressive election reform.

Sen. Boxer signed on but the challenge failed in the House & Senate.
https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-2005-jan-07-na-electoral7-story.html

In 2001, 13 House Democrats objected to Florida's 25 electoral votes based on claims of voter disenfranchisement & voting irregularities.

They failed to get a signature from a Senate counterpart & the challenge died. 
https://www.nytimes.com/2001/01/07/us/over-some-objections-congress-certifies-electoral-vote.html

To object to a state's Electoral College results, a member of the House & a member of the Senate must sign on.

Over the last 20 years, the Electoral College's results have been challenged several times. Notably in 2001, 2005 and 2017.

And you guessed it, all by Democrats.

To object to a state's Electoral College results, a member of the House & a member of the Senate must sign on.

Over the last 20 years, the Electoral College's results have been challenged several times. Notably in 2001, 2005 and 2017.

And you guessed it, all by Democrats.

Second, the House & Senate must convene in a joint-session to review electoral votes.

Only after both chambers object or affirm the Electoral College's results is the President-Elect officially declared.

Going all the way back to Rutherford B. Hayes' election in 1876, Congress has played a role in ensuring our elections are free & fair.

The Electoral Count Act of 1877 gives both the House & Senate the ability to object to Electoral College votes.

First, each state is given electors based on population.

Electors across all states cast 1 vote which is certified by its respective state.

State ballots are then sent to the U.S. Congress to count, certify validity, object (or not) & declare the results (majority required).

There's been a lot of confusion & misinformation going around about the Electoral College, the role of Congress & what it means for the 2020 election.

8/ Those two energy storage titles were combined into Section 3201 of the Omnibus spending bill (page 995) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EqaqA2UW4AEMbJH.png

7/ In parallel, my friend @RepBillFoster had introduced the Battery Energy Storage Technology (BEST) Act to accelerate R&D into advanced energy storage technology which had similar cross-aisle and cross-Capitol support. https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/2986?q=%7B%22search%22%3A%5B%22grid+energy+storage%22%5D%7D&s=3&r=1

5/ That's a solvable problem, either through increased transmission capacity or properly sited energy storage that can absorb & release that intermittent energy.  Local NIMBY issues make transmission siting hard (but I have some thoughts on that for the 117th Congress...)
4/ e.g., running at half load so they could quickly ramp up or down in response to surges up or down of renewable capacity.

3/ As large volumes of intermittent (e.g., wind and solar) renewables came on line that exceeded the ability of a given region of the grid to export/import to balance, inefficient quick-ramping gas-fired power plants were coming on line to load-balance.

2/ The rise was just about exactly matched by increased MWh from comparatively inefficient simple cycle gas turbine power plants.   This was driven substantially, if paradoxically by the success of renewable energy.
